indicators.justification:
As part of its commitments under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), Uruguay publishes information about greenhouse gas emissions (1). The data is available in open formants in the National Open Data Catalog (2), from the nineties to 2017.

##Sources:
1. https://visualizador.gobiernoabierto.gub.uy/visualizador/api/repos/%3Apublic%3Aorganismos%3Aambiente%3Avisualizador_inventario.wcdf/generatedContent
2. https://catalogodatos.gub.uy/dataset/ambiente_ingei

responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
Nationally published data includes detailed information on greenhouse gas emissions and targets reported to the UNFCCC.
Data contains detailed information on sources of greenhouse gas emissions.
Emissions data includes, or site where emissions data is made available links to, details of land use effects on emissions.
The dataset contains unique identifiers for greenhouse gas emissions that allow easy assessment across inventories, reduction commitments, and sources.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
The Species Database is made available by several national entities directly involved in the conservation of species. The database allow users to search species using different filters, including geographical locations. It includes information about species group, family, scientific name, and common name. It also states if the specie is native and if it's protected and/or threatened. However, there isn't information about the database last update and it can not be downloaded in an open format.

##Sources:
https://www.ambiente.gub.uy/especies/

indicators.justification:
The Environment Ministry is responsable for the National Environmental Observatory. In its website, citizens can access relevant information about climate vulnerability (1). In the Open Data section, over 25 datasets are available. These include data about water quality, air quality, management of industrial and agroindustrial wastes, biosecurity, etc.(2). Interactive tools and visualizations are available for issues like air o water quality.  


##sources
1. https://www.ambiente.gub.uy/oan/
2. https://www.ambiente.gub.uy/oan/datos-abiertos/

The information about final beneficial ownership of companies is collect by the Central Bank of Uruguay but it is not public. It is declared as confidential by the Law 19.484 (1).

indicators.justification:
The Micro, Small and Medium Companies Directory is anual database -since 2016- that includes basic information on these business (1). The responsable for the datasets is the Statistics National Institute in agreement with the National Tax Office (2). However, data is not openly available as special permission is required to access individual data (3).

indicators.justification:
Information about Uruguay's vital statistics (births, deaths and newborns) is available in a website provided by the Ministry of Health. The information is broad and free. It's updated to last year and can be downloaded in ods format.

##Sources: 
https://uins.msp.gub.uy/

Mortality information includes data about age, sex and/or gender, geographic location, and cause of death.
Birth information includes data about sex and/or assigned gender of child, gestational age, and birth weight.
Birth information includes data about live-birth order and interval between last and previous live births to mother.
Birth information includes data about place of occurrence, place of usual residence of mother, and month of occurrence.
Birth information includes data about place of registration and month of registration.
Birth information includes data about age, educational attainment, and ethnic and/or national group of mother.
Birth information includes data about age of father and place of usual residence.
Birth information includes data about site of delivery, attendant at birth, and month in which prenatal care began.

indicators.justification:
Information about capacity of the healthcare system is only available in relation to the ICUs. About them, information provided by the government shows the total of beds, number of beds available, total occupation of beds and reasons (COVID-19, Severe Acute Respiratory Syndrome and other conditions), among other indicators. The information is updated daily. There isn't more information about other capacity related issues.

##Sources:
https://www.gub.uy/sistema-nacional-emergencias/pagina-embebida/visualizador-ocupacion-cci-personas-adultas

indicators.justification: The Ministry of Health has implemented the COVID-19 Vaccination Data Monitor in 2021. The website presents information about number of doses administered, age and geographical distribution of vaccinated population. Data is also available in open formats in the National Open Data Catalog.

indicators.justification:
In general, data on land tenure is not public in Uruguay. The only exception are the individuals or groups beneficiaries of the National Colonization Institute (known as "colonos"), for whom open data about who they are and basic features of the land the have/use is available and update (1). The publication of this information is stated by a resolution of the institute, from December 2019 (2).

##sources
1. https://www.colonizacion.com.uy/colonos-beneficiarios-de-la-politica-del-inc
2. Resolución 22/Acta 5486: https://www.colonizacion.com.uy/documents/20182/25502/ACTA+N.%C2%BA+5486+DEL+26-12-2019.pdf/12a83960-4248-4af5-95a4-b24242b64822?version=1.0

indicators.justification:
The Budget Transparency Portal (1) provides updated, disaggregated and updated information on national entities budgets and spending. Its main tool is the app ""Where does our taxes go?" which shows national budget by cross-cutting areas and organisms (2). The portal has also an open data section, where several datasets on budget, financial results, public corporations and more, can be downloaded (3). 

##Sources: 
1.https://transparenciapresupuestaria.opp.gub.uy/ 
2.https://transparenciapresupuestaria.opp.gub.uy/inicio/presupuesto-nacional/a-d%C3%B3nde-van-nuestros-impuestos
3. https://transparenciapresupuestaria.opp.gub.uy/inicio/datos-abiertos

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
There is structured data available on the executive budget proposal in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data available on amended budgets (when applicable) or amendments of the enacted budget.
There is structured data available on the approved or enacted budget in gross terms, including spending on annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about government budget execution or spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis, including spending in annual and multi-annual investment projects.
There is structured data about the government's extrabudgetary funds spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about the government's social security spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
There is structured data about public corporations' spending, in gross terms and on an accrual basis.
Budget entries have administrative classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have economic classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have functional classifications to an internationally agreed standard.
Budget entries have program classifications according to an internationally agreed standard.
Information about individual financial transactions or expenditures is available at the most disaggregated level of the economic classification level.
Data is disaggregated by cross-cutting programs, or issues such as SDGs, climate action, gender budgeting, etc,
The data contains common identifiers to connect budget and budget performance data.
The data contains identifiers that can be used to connect budget data with data on major projects (e.g., infrastructure construction) and procurement processes.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.
Data is timely and updated.
Historical data is available that allows users to track change over time.
Data is provided in machine-readable format(s)
The machine-readable dataset is available as a whole

indicators.justification:
The National Transparency and Public Ethics Board publishes on its website the sworn statements of the president, vice-president, ministers, local authorities, senators and representatives, among others (1,2). The statements are current but not available in open formats.

indicators.justification:
As part of its commitments in the 4th Open Government Plan, the national electoral authority published the financial information of the political parties (established in Law 18,484) in an open format, for the last electoral cycle (1). The data includes income and spending of each political party, list and candidate (2).

indicators.justification:
The agency for the Access to Public Information (UAIP) publishes an annual report with general data on compliance with the regulation. The information includes number of requests, reservation or confidentiality statements, and compliance with deadlines. The data refer exclusively to the public entities that reported to the agency, but these are not all organisms obligated by law (1,2)

indicators.justification:
Public consultations are not regulated by a legal framework in Uruguay. Therefore, only a few agencies carry out public consultations. Examples that do, are the Energy and Water Services agency (URSEC) and the Electronic Government agency (AGESIC). Both URSEC and AGESIC inform about regulation being discussed in the consultations, publish citizens' comments and the final result of the process (1,2). Non of them publish this information in public formats.

##sources
1. http://dominoapps.ursea.gub.uy/web/consultaspublicas.nsf
2. https://www.gub.uy/participacionciudadana/consultapublica/legislation_proposals?is_proposal=false

responses.response_text: Data is available from government, or because of government actions.
responses.subquestion_text: Is this data available online in any form?
The data includes proposed regulations.
The data includes a full set of public comments generated through public consultation processes.
The data includes supporting information, such as notices of intent and reasoned responses.
The data includes final regulations and justifications.
The data includes details of challenges to regulations that have passed through public consultation processes, as well as the results of these challenges.
Dataset is available free of charge.
Data is openly licensed.
Data is available in all the country’s official or national languages. If the country has no official or national languages, data is available in the major languages of the country.
There are accessible and open official tools available to help users explore data.

indicators.justification:
Uruguay publishes individual tenders and awards in the Public Procurement Regulatory Agency (1). Also, this agency has adopted the Open Contracting Data Standard in 2017 (2). Historial information from 2002 onwards has been also adapted to the OCDS (3). And finally, the agency has its own observatory where people can consult aggregated information (4).

indicators.justification:
The most importan open government data initiative is the National Open Data Catalog, which is operative since 2012 (1). In the catalog, there are 2.230 datasets available and over 50 publishers, most of which are government's agencies (2).

indicators.justification:
The design and implementation policies about open government and open data are still pending for many local governments in Uruguay. Although some of them have incorporated open data sessions in their websites, participate in the Open Data Catalog or promote applications that reuse data, this is not yet widespread at the national level (1,2,3,4,5,6). The great exception is Montevideo, which does have an open government policy and has even implemented the Open Data Observatory (7).

indicators.justification:
AGESIC, in partnership with agencies working on data protection and access to public information, organized and promoted several training initiatives during 2019-2021(1,2). One of the most relevant is the training session within the "Datos 360°" initiative and the "Technological Days", which include topics like regulations, data analysis and innovative tools (3). General public servants and technicians can participate.

indicators.justification:
Law 19.484 and its regulatory decree establish the registry of beneficial ownership of companies (1,2,3). It is implemented by the Central Bank of Uruguay. In general, the subjects obliged to identify the final beneficiaries are corporations, funds and investment funds, foundations, economic interest groups, among others. The information in the Final Beneficiaries Registry is defined as secret by the same law, and can only be accessed by some public bodies.

indicators.justification:
The "Principles and Strategic Lines for the Electronic Government" decree (2009) establishes accessibility as one of the principle for the digital government strategy (1). More recently, several national institutions have made the Accessibility Statement, by which they undertake to adopt measures for all contents to be accesible, including their compliance with WCAG2 standards (2,3,4,5,6,7).

indicators.justification:
Since 2019, AGESIC has been working in the Framework for Data Quality Management that includes tools, techniques, standards, processes and good practices related to data quality (1)(2). This guideline is still in development. (3) Along with this, AGESIC also has the The Guide for publishing open data, covering important aspects about data publication.

indicators.justification:
The main precedent for data sharing in Uruguay is the Interoperability Platform, created by an Executive decree in 2013 (1). To implement the platform and encourage its use, AGESIC has developed a set of guides (2). More recently, two other important policies to promote data sharing have been implemented: the Data Reference Model and the Data Platform (3,4).

indicators.justification:
Since 2008, Uruguay has a broad and comprehensive legal framework that guarantees the protection of personal data. This is stated in the Law 18.331 and its regulatory Decrete 414/009 (1,2). Further, Law 19.670 (articles 37 to 40) -and Decrete 64/2020- widen the scope of application of the Law 18.331 to international data holders and establishes new obligations for data holders in general (3,4).

4. https://www.impo.com.uy/bases/decretos/64-2020

indicators.justification:
Uruguay approved the obligation for public entities to publish standard information using open data formats in the Budget Law of 2015 (Law 19.355) (1). In 2017, approved the Decrete 54/017 which establishes general guidance for the publication of open data (2). This framework states a general definition of open data, as well as principles, formats and scope that it should follow. Finally, the normative also creates the Uruguay Open Data License.

2. https://www.impo.com.uy/bases/decretos-originales/54-2017#ANEXO

indicators.justification:
The article 82 of the Law 19.355 and the Decree 54/017, establish that a minimum information on assigned budget and its execution must be publish for every public entity in open format (1,2). Further guidance on technicalities are stipulated in the document "Technical Guidelines for Opening Open Data" (3).

The laws 17.060 and 19.340 indicate that public officials must make a declaration on their income, assets, companies, assets and liabilities, as well as their spouses. The National Transparency and Public Ethics Board is responsable for collecting and publishing this declarations (1,2,3).

indicators.justification:
In Uruguay, there isn't a legal framework for lobby activities. Although it is possible to know which organizations or individuals participate in parliamentary committees, on the Parliament website, there is no specific record of this, nor is there an obligation to do so. National authorities and academics have warned about the need to generate regulations in this regard (1,2).

The Law 18.485 regulates the functioning of the political parties in Uruguay, it was approved in 2009 (1,2). It states conditions for public and private funding, including a threshold for for anonymous donations, and how parties must present their accountability to the electoral authority.

indicators.justification:
In Uruguay, there isn't a legal framework regulating public consultations for rulemaking. However, there are some examples of this practice. The Energy and Water Services Regulatory Agency (URSEC) has a stated procedure for public consultations, that dates from 2002 (1). Other national agencies have also implement public consultations in the last years (2,3,4).

The rules/guidance require that data is regularly updated.
The rules/guidance support the collection of structured data.

responses.response_text: They cover one or more localities and are a representative example of the kind of rules/guidance that can be found for all, or most, localities.
responses.subquestion_text: How comprehensive, in terms of jurisdiction, is the coverage of the laws, regulations, policies, or guidance assessed for this question?

indicators.justification:
The Law 18.381, which state the right to access public information and the procedures to do it, mandate to public entities to present an annual report on their compliance with the regulation (1) and a semestral report on their decisions about reserved information (2). However, these reports are not public.

indicators.justification:
The Due Diligence is established in the law against money laundering (Law 19.574) and its decree 379/018 (1,2). There is evidence of legal firms and national banks carrying out due diligence measures (3,4,5). However, there isn't information on types and sources used.

indicators.justification:
Datasets related to campaign donations, political party finances and affidavits of political officials are usually used by the media. In this way, cases have been identified, for example, of illegal financing (1,2). Uses by other institutions -such as civil society or academia- do not appear for the study period.

indicators.justification: Evidence about government procurement data being used to improve procurement practice is very little. Most important projects come from the procurement national authority (ARCE) and civil society.

responses.response_text: There is evidence of isolated uses or pilot projects.

There is evidence of government procurement data being presented through data-driven dashboards.
There is evidence of government procurement data being used for red flag analysis.
There is evidence that government procurement data is being analyzed to improve access to procurement opportunities for marginalized groups.
There is evidence of government procurement data being analysed to support sustainable / environmental procurement.
